Award.AwardTitle: Avifauna Persistence and Vulnerabilities: Island Biogeography Across Long Time Scales

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in climate and in other natural environmental factors as well as human-related land-use changes have had some of the greatest impacts on biodiversity. With the goal of enhancing understanding of historic biogeography, this research project will investigate questions about the persistence versus loss of species under a variety of climate-induced conditions and human-caused environmental change. The project will develop new insights regarding how species and ecosystems respond to the direct and indirect effects of changes in climate, including warmer temperatures and rising sea levels. A deeper understanding of species responses to the past effects of climate and other global changes will improve capabilities to forecast the impacts of future changes. Project results will contribute to scientific understanding of how global changes affect ecosystems and the services they provide to humans. The findings will help inform policy makers, governmental agencies, and resource administrators as they assess appropriate courses of action to mitigate effects of future climate change. This project also will strengthen international research collaborations among U.S. and Caribbean scientists and institutions.

Using islands as microcosms for understanding human interactions with the environment, this project will analyze species traits of land-bird communities in terms of their resilience versus vulnerability from multiple contexts. It will combine data about paleontology, radiocarbon chronology, paleoclimate, and modern plant and animal communities to develop a rigorous model of long-term biotic change. Species-level identifications of fossils will portray changes in species communities, which will be evaluated in light of their specific life-history traits, such as climatic niche, habitat preference, feeding guild, and range attributes (widespread vs. endemic). An innovative form of species distribution modeling will be used to characterize the climatically suitable habitat or "climate envelope" for each species and develop quantitative, empirical, predictive models of species-environment relationships. Project findings will provide new perspectives about the relationships among contemporary species distributions and climate (and other environmental predictors). They also will permit the investigators to "hindcast" species distributions in previous time periods. Given wide-spread concerns about ongoing and future impacts of natural environmental and human-related changes on biogeography and biodiversity, this project will provide data-rich context and validation for research investigations that previously have tended to rely on modeling and projections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Intellectual Merit: We examined patterns of survival vs. extinction of wildlife species over long time frames, developing a practical perspective on how biodiversity responds to the direct and indirect effects of climate change. We predicted lower rates of species loss from environmental changes on large than small islands.  We furthermore predicted less ecological change on large islands than on small islands after human arrival because inherent features of large islands (higher elevation, more rugged topography, more diverse climate and habitats) tend to provide species refugia and slow extinction rates.

We studied prehistoric and modern animal communities on small islands in The Bahamas, where extremely well-preserved vertebrate fossils have provided unparalleled evidence of changes in the terrestrial vertebrate communities since the last ice age (more than 10,000 years ago) and also across the past 10 millennia of warmer climates and higher sea levels. Over 7000 vertebrate fossils were recovered by scuba divers from Sawmill Sink on the island of Abaco, from which we identified 96 species of vertebrates in late Pleistocene (ice age) deposits. We also completed the study of two other major sets of Bahamian ice age bird fossils from dry caves on New Providence and Long Island, the latter based on a major excavation we did in December 2017. The dramatic global warming and sea level rise that took place at the end of the last ice age (from 18,000 to 9000 years ago) led to the loss of at least 17 species of birds on Abaco, with most of these species documented as lost from New Providence and Long Island as well. At least 23 species of reptiles, birds, and mammals persisted through these major environmental changes but were unable to survive the last millennium of human activity. Through extensive radiocarbon dating, we documented the timing of extinction of the two largest reptiles that once occupied the Bahamas, giant tortoises and Cuban crocodile whose extinctions took place about 800-900 years ago, within a century or two of the first arrival of prehistoric peoples. Prehistoric humans had profound impacts, with cascading effects on biotic communities, since their arrival in Bahamian islands about 1,000 years ago.

            Our analysis of large islands focused on the Greater Antillean island of Hispaniola, where we surveyed plants, amphibians, reptiles, and birds along an elevation gradient in the unique tropical dry forest of Sierra Mart?n Garc?a National Park. We found that a number of species endemic to either Hispaniola or to the West Indian region were widespread along the elevation gradient. We discovered human-mediated impacts on Hispaniola resembling those found in the Bahamas, although the losses seem to be spread over much of the 5 or 6 millennia that people have lived on this large island.

            Whether in the Bahamas or Hispaniola, our data suggest that being a habitat generalist is a highly favorable trait for birds to maintain long-term viable populations. Our surveys of living vertebrates do reveal, however, that the Bahamian amphibian and reptile communities now include a growing number of species and populations of non-native species. Such is not the case in Hispaniola.  Documenting the potential effects of invasive species on native species will be a fertile ground for future research. We are embarking on a new era in the historical island biogeography, where we can track changes in species composition through time with unprecedented accuracy and precision.

 

Broader Impacts: Our research underscores that conservation planning aimed at mitigating future impacts on plant and animal communities should consider not only direct climate change but also sea level rise and other factors, including land use change, invasive species, and altered fire regimes. Our project also contributed to science-technology-math-engineering (STEM) education by providing hands-on training in important field and laboratory techniques to students and collaborators in both the U.S. and The Bahamas. These techniques range from collecting vegetation data and conducting computer-based modeling to excavating and identifying fossils. We also recruited two Bahamian students to the University of Florida, where they have received Masters degrees in Museum Studies. A Hispaniolan student that we recruited now is beginning a PhD program at UF. Our program of community engagement, including numerous lectures and public programs in the islands and in the U.S., is fostering an improved understanding of long-term environmental change. Abaco Blue Holes National Park was established in late 2015 partly as a result of our demonstrating the scientific value of the area. Our data from Sierra Mart?n Garc?a National Park is helping the government of the Dominican Republic in managing that national park.

On a sad note, Hurricane Dorian devastated the island of Abaco, where much of our research has taken place, in September 2019. Even though our grant is finished, we continue to work with our Bahamian colleagues in the difficult task of re-building their scientific infrastructure.
